courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Foundations of Health Assessment
courseDescription: This didactic and laboratory course emphasizes the assessment phase of the nursing process.  Supervised practice, faculty demonstration, and self-paced learning in the audio-visual laboratory, simulation laboratory and selected clinical sites facilitate skill acquisition in health assessment and health history interviewing. Pre- or
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a clinical environment

courseDescription: This course emphasizes the physical assessment phase of the nursing process. For registered nurse students only.

courseTitle: Theoretical Foundation of Professional Nursing Practice
courseDescription: This course focuses on selected nursing models, concepts, and theories as supporting frameworks for professional nursing practice.  Emphasis is placed on the utilization of nursing theory as a methodology for improving nursing practice in various client situations and practice settings.  For registered nurse students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to apply nursing theory in different practice settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to effectively communicate nursing theories
Capacity to work well with clients in various situations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to use nursing theory to solve problems
Capacity to analyze and interpret client situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead in the application of nursing theories
Capacity to organize and manage nursing practice based on various theories

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Introduction to Nutrition/Normal Nutrition
courseDescription: This course focuses on concepts of normal nutrition. Emphasis is placed on understanding the impact of various nutrients on the body.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of nutritional impacts on the body

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Nutrition of Nursing Practice
courseDescription: This course builds upon NURSÂ 310 and introduces the student to selected therapeutic diets. Emphasis is placed on specific diets associated with selected alterations in adaptation and the adult with behavioral issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of specific diets for certain health conditions
Ability to adapt diets for adults with behavioral issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding patient dietary needs and preferences
Interacting with patients with behavioral issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting diets for specific health conditions

courseDescription: Emphasis is on concepts and theories that are fundamental to professional nursing practice, the nursing process, and therapeutic nurse-patient communication.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of therapeutic nurse-patient communication techniques
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to establish rapport with patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of the nursing process for patient care
Adaptive decision-making based on patient needs

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Clinical Foundations of Practice
courseDescription: This clinical course focuses on the assessment and basic care of the hospitalized adult client. Application of the nursing process, health assessment, and clinical nursing techniques are implemented using concepts and theories that underlie professional nursing practice.

This lecture course focuses on the adult who is experiencing selected alterations and/or adaptations in organ system function such as elimination, immune system/cellular regulation, hematological system, fluid balance, temperature regulation and nutritional balances. Focus is also on the adult experiencing pain, inflammation and other selected system alterations. Emphasis is on the use of the nursing process to assist adult patients to adapt to alterations/adaptations in function of systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessment and management of pain and inflammation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of patient adaptations to alterations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Delegating tasks within a healthcare team

courseTitle: Health Continuum: Clinical Management Adult Health I
courseDescription: This clinical course focuses on the nursing process with adult clients experiencing alterations/adaptations in bodily defense mechanisms. The concepts inclusive in the didactic component will be actualized in general medical surgical units and oncology units.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explanation of medical conditions and treatments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of bodily defense mechanism alterations/adaptations

courseDescription: This lecture course focuses on the theoretical and applied concepts related to the care of families experiencing pregnancy and childbirth. Emphasis is on the dynamic familial, societal, psychological and physiological changes that occur in this stage of family and personal development. The assistive role of the nurse and as a family-centered provider of care is a major focus.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of theoretical concepts in family care
Knowledge of physiological changes during pregnancy and childbirth
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying psychological concepts in family care
Assessing and addressing societal changes impacting family health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading as a family-centered provider of care

courseTitle: Health Continuum: Clinical Management of the Growing Family
courseDescription: This clinical course provides the opportunity for planning and provision of nursing care to the childbearing family. Emphasis is on the use of the nursing process to plan, provide and coordinate quality care. Students are expected to demonstrate responsibility and accountability for personal actions as well as a respect for families and clients.

courseTitle: Health Continuum: Behavioral Issues, Altered Cognition and Coping
courseDescription: This lecture course focuses on psychotherapeutic processes across the lifespan. Building on foundations from the social and behavioral sciences, emphasis is on the use of the nursing process in providing care to clients with acute and chronic illness in a variety of psychiatric settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of social and behavioral sciences
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with healthcare professionals in psychiatric settings
Empathy and understanding towards clients with acute and chronic illness
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving in acute and chronic illness scenarios
Analyzing behavioral and cognitive changes in patients
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and managing nursing care for patients
Organization of care plans according to client's needs

courseTitle: Clinical Management of Patients with Behavioral Issues, Altered Cognition and Coping
courseDescription: This clinical course provides a mechanism for students to perform mental health assessments, plan nursing care, practice therapeutic communication techniques and observe group processes in both inpatient and outpatient settings.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating care in inpatient and outpatient settings

courseDescription: Emphasis is placed on current information and research findings about the role of genetics in health. Students completing this course will be better prepared to incorporate genetic information and technology when providing care to clients.  A student receiving credit for NURSÂ 355 cannot receive credit for NURSÂ 455.
Technical and Digital Skills: Usage of genetic information and technology in healthcare
Research and analysis of current genetic information
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting genetic information for client care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying genetic research findings to nursing practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Incorporating genetic knowledge into nursing care plans
Leading in the application of genetic technology in healthcare

courseDescription: This introductory course to global health emphasizes the major underlying determinants of poor health and the relationship between health and political, social, and economic development. Students will be introduced to global effects on the health of populations worldwide, current and future challenges to global health and the role of primary health care providers in meeting that challenge. (A student receiving credit for NURSÂ 356 cannot receive credit for NURSÂ 456.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective collaboration with diverse global health care teams
Cultural sensitivity and understanding for global health contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social, political, and economic factors influencing global health
Understanding and addressing global health challenges
Critical evaluation of health and development policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for global health interventions
Leadership in primary health care provision

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of the need to improve end of life care and the role of nursing as a member of the interdisciplinary team in providing quality care. Basic principals of palliative care are presented within a quality of life (QOL) framework. Palliative care nursing care combines caring, communication, knowledge, and skill. Clinical issues to include expert assessment skills and aggressive pain and symptom management as well as the psychological, social, and spiritual care of patients and families experiencing a life threatening progressive illness will be discussed. Caring for the dying means not only "doing for" but also "being with". Students will be provided the opportunity to use introspection to clarify their own feelings related to the dying process. A student receiving credit for NURSÂ 357 cannot receive credit for NURSÂ 457.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and families
Being with patients and families during difficult times
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Self-introspection related to the dying process

courseDescription: The study of selected topics in professional nursing practice; designed to provide an in-depth exploration of current nursing issues.

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Research as Foundation for Practice
courseDescription: This course focuses on the theories and concepts utilized in the scientific investigation of nursing practice. Content emphasizes the development of skills necessary to be a consumer of nursing research.

courseTitle: Practicum: Studies in Clinical Nursing Practice
courseDescription: The study of selected clinical practice applications in professional nursing practice; designed to provide an in-depth practicum in selected nursing practice areas.  Students must have specific practicum arrangements (ex: externship) prior to registration.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital health record systems

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Pharmacology for Nursing Practice I
courseDescription: This course is designed to involve the student in the application of the nursing process to clinical situations involving drug therapy.

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Pharmacology Across the Continuum
courseDescription: This course is designed to involve nursing students in the practical application of the nursing process in clinical pharmaco-therapeutics related to selected concepts.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and adaptation of treatment plans

courseDescription: This is an advanced placement course for nursing students concurrently enrolled in level 1 nursing coursework with an approved partner nursing program. After successful completion of the didactic coursework and clinical requirements at the partner institution, the student will be awarded experiential learning credits.

This is an advanced placement course for nursing students concurrently enrolled in level 2 nursing coursework with an approved partner nursing program. After successful completion of the didactic coursework and clinical requirements at the partner institution, the student will be awarded experiential learning credits.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of medical technology and equipment

courseDescription: This is an advanced placement course for nursing students concurrently enrolled in level 3 nursing coursework with an approved partner nursing program. After successful completion of the didactic coursework and clinical requirements at the partner institution, the student will be awarded experiential learning credits.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Active listening and empathy in patient care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk assessment and mitigation in healthcare

courseDescription: This is an advanced placement course for nursing students concurrently enrolled in level 4 nursing coursework with an approved partner nursing program. After successful completion of the didactic coursework and clinical requirements at the partner institution, the student will be awarded experiential learning credits. Proof of licensure as a registered nurse is required prior to awarding the level 4 experiential learning credits.

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Research as Foundation for Practice
courseDescription: This course focuses on the theories and concepts utilized in the scientific investigation of nursing practice. Content emphasizes the development of skills necessary to be a consumer of nursing research.  Open to Honors Program students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of scientific investigation theories and concepts
Understanding and application of nursing research methodologies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of research methodologies and findings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking responsibility for learning and knowledge acquisition

courseDescription: Focuses on basic hygiene, comfort and safety skills required of health professionals providing diagnostic and/or supportive therapies to clients in a health care facility.  May not be taken as required elective by nursing majors.  Open to nuclear medicine technology students only.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of patient comfort and safety
Implementation of hygiene and safety protocols

courseDescription: Selected health-related topics of interest.  Course descriptions and prerequisites are available from the chief academic advisor.
Nursing majors only. Selected health-related topics of interest to nursing majors. Course descriptions and prerequisites are available from the chief academic advisor.
Independent study of selected topics.

This advanced placement credit is awarded to the registered nurse who has demonstrated knowledge of selected basic clinical nursing concepts for the provision of nursing care to individuals experiencing health deviations.  Awarded upon completion of 14 credits in major. Registered nurse students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic clinical nursing concepts
Knowledge of nursing care provision for individuals experiencing health deviations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying clinical nursing concepts for problem-solving

courseTitle: Introduction to Professional Development for Baccalaureate Nursing Practice
courseDescription: This course focuses on basic skills required for success in the post-licensure baccalaureate nursing program.  Emphasis is placed on professional development for baccalaureate nursing practice.  Selected skills to be acquired include introduction to the development of a professional portfolio, APA professional writing format, information literacy in nursing literature and professional communication strategies.  For registered nurse students only.

courseTitle: Role Development for the Baccalaureate Nurse as Educator
courseDescription: This course focuses on further development of the baccalaureate nursing student with an emphasis on expanding critical thinking skills, teaching-learning theories and application, professional resume development and exploration of nursing specialties and practice roles.  For registered nursing students only.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Exploration and analysis of nursing specialties and practice roles

courseDescription: This course facilitates the completion of a professional portfolio for the post-licensure baccalaureate nursing student. Emphasis is on advanced professional communication strategies and reflective processes for professional role expansion and development. For registered nurse students only. NURSÂ 403 may only be taken in the final semester of the nursing curriculum.

This lecture course focuses on the adult experiencing multisystem alterations/adaptations. Emphasis is on the use of the nursing process to assist adult clients to adapt to multisystem alterations/adaptations related insults.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and management of multisystem alterations/adaptations

courseTitle: Ethics, Law, Economics & Health Policy: Application to Quality Nursing Practice
courseDescription: This course examines ethics, law, economics and health policy that influence nursing practice, the health care system, and quality patient care.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of legal aspects in nursing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of economic factors influencing nursing practice
Analysis of legal issues in nursing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing patient care based on ethical, legal, and economic considerations

courseDescription: This course focuses on information management and the utilization of patient care technologies to improve the patient experience of care (quality, satisfaction, safety), improve the health of populations, and reduce cost. Students will develop knowledge, skills and attitudes related to nursing informatics through readings, online discussions, case studies and exploration and use of electronic modalities.

courseTitle: Health Continuum: Clinical Management of Children of the Family
courseDescription: This clinical course emphasizes the provision of nursing care to infants and children suffering from acute and chronic illnesses. Through the use of the nursing process, students provide and coordinate care, serving as client advocates. Students are expected to demonstrate responsibility for personal actions related to the practice of nursing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Provision of nursing care to infants and children
Use of nursing process in care coordination
Understanding of acute and chronic illnesses in children
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and their families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing and implementing nursing care plans
Assessing effects of acute and chronic illnesses on a child's health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Responsibility for personal actions in nursing practice

courseTitle: Heath Continuum: Children of the Family
courseDescription: This lecture course provides a basis for understanding the nursing care of children of various ages. Emphasis is on the use of the nursing process to assist children as they encounter acute and chronic illnesses. The nurse's communication with and education of the family and child as individuals or as part of a group are discussed as a means of achieving the goal of comprehensive individualized child care in the home and health care settings.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with children and families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing children's health problems
Adapting care strategies to individual child's needs
Analyzing the impact of illnesses on children
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading patient and family education initiatives

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Contemporary Issues in Nursing Care of the Older Adult
courseDescription: This course focuses on the nursing needs of the well gerontological client. Emphasis is on the multi-complex needs of the older adult.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting care plans for complex needs

courseDescription: This course introduces the theoretical and applied concepts necessary to assist individuals with potential or actual disabilities prevent further functional dependence or restore maximum levels of function.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of theoretical concepts related to disability prevention and recovery
Applied knowledge of functional restoration techniques
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate effectively with individuals with potential or actual disabilities
Empathy and understanding towards individuals with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to assess the level of functional dependence
Analytical skills to devise recovery plans for maximum restoration of function
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to organize and manage recovery plans
Leadership skills to guide individuals through their recovery process

courseTitle: Heath Continuum: Clinical Management of Recovery
courseDescription: This clinical course focuses on using the nursing process to assist the recovery of individuals with disabilities prevent further functional dependence or restore maximum levels of function. Collaborative team approaches are stressed.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of recovery plans based on patient response

courseTitle: Health Continuum: Clinical Management Adult Health Nursing II
courseDescription: This clinical course emphasizes the provision of nursing care to clients who are experiencing alterations/adaptations in organ system functions. Through the use of the nursing process, students will provide and coordinate care and serve as client advocates in a variety of settings.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and healthcare professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and interpretation of organ system function alterations

courseDescription: This elective clinical and didactic course is designed for final semester pre-licensure students who are requesting adult critical care (CC) or emergency department (ED) Role Transition preceptorship placement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in adult critical care procedures

courseDescription: Emphasis is placed on current information & research findings about the role of genetics in health. Students completing this course will be better prepared to incorporate genetic information and technology when providing care to clients. A student receiving credit for NURSÂ 355 cannot receive credit for NURSÂ 455.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of genetic information
Utilization of genetic technology in patient care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integrating genetic information into patient care plans
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Keeping up-to-date with current genetic health information
Coordinating genetic technology in nursing practice

courseDescription: This introductory course to global health emphasizes the major underlying determinants of poor health and the relationship between health and political, social, and economic development. Students will be introduced to. global effects on the health of populations worldwide, current and future challenges to global health and the role of primary health care providers in meeting that challenge. (A student receiving credit for NURSÂ 456 cannot receive credit for NURSÂ 356.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of the health effects of political, social, and economic development
Understanding of role of primary health care providers in global health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate global health issues effectively
Understanding and respecting cultural perspectives in global health
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of health effects on populations worldwide
Ability to identify and address future challenges to global health
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and organizing health initiatives in a global context
Strategic planning for global health issues

courseDescription: This course provides an overview of the need to improve end of life care and the role of nursing as a member of the interdisciplinary team in providing quality care. Basic principles of palliative care are presented within a quality of life (QOL) framework. Palliative care nursing care combines caring, communication, knowledge, and skill. Clinical issues to include expert assessment skills and aggressive pain and symptom management as well as the psychological, social, and spiritual care of patients and families experiencing a life threatening progressive illness will be discussed. Caring for the dying means not only "doing for" but also "being with". Students will be provided the opportunity to use introspection to clarify their own feelings related to the dying process. A student receiving credit for NURSÂ 357 cannot receive credit for NURSÂ 457.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Managing complex emotional and physical symptoms
Addressing psychological, social, and spiritual concerns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating palliative care within a team
Balancing care tasks and emotional support
Understanding and navigating the dying process

courseDescription: The study of selected topics in professional nursing practice; designed to provide an in-depth exploration of current nursing issues.

In this course, students learn to improve the health of individuals, families, and communities in primary care settings.  Emphasis is on health education, health promotion and disease prevention, and management of chronic illnesses, especially for underserved populations and veterans.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cultural competence with underserved populations and veterans
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of individual health scenarios

courseTitle: Nursing in the Health Care System Community I
courseDescription: This course focuses on family and community health nursing. Content emphasizes concepts and themes of families and communities and the use of the nursing process to assist in promoting and maintaining health. Application of course concepts through experience and interactions with health care coalition groups is emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interactions with health care coalition groups

courseTitle: Nursing in the Health Care System: Community Interactions I
courseDescription: This clinical course provides opportunity for application of concepts and themes of families and communities through experience and interactions with health care coalition groups.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with health care coalition groups

courseTitle: Nursing in the Health Care System: Community II
courseDescription: This course focuses on the continued development of concepts related to family and community health nursing. Content emphasizes development of strategies to facilitate application of concepts and themes of families and communities. The nursing process is used to assist in promoting and maintaining health.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with families and communities

courseTitle: Nursing in the Health Care System: Community Interactions II
courseDescription: Application of course concepts through experience and interactions with healthcare coalition groups are emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting with various healthcare coalition groups
Conveying medical information to non-medical personnel
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of healthcare trends and patterns
Problem-solving in a health care context

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Pharmacology for Nursing Practice II
courseDescription: This course is designed to involve nursing students in the practical application of the nursing process in clinical pharmacotherapeutics related to selected concepts.

courseTitle: Nursing in the Health Care System: Leadership
courseDescription: This course focuses on utilization of strategies from leadership, management systems and change theories to facilitate professional nursing practice. Emphasis is placed on the professional nurse as a leader in the health care system. The influence of organizational behavior, professional image and case management on nursing practice is examined. This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpersonal relations in a healthcare setting

courseDescription: This capstone course is a practicum experience in which students apply theoretical, conceptual and psychomotor learning in a structured clinical environment under the supervision of a staff preceptor. The experience is designed to assist the student to facilitate the transition to the role of the baccalaureate generalist nurse.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing transition to baccalaureate generalist nurse role

courseDescription: This course focuses on utilization of strategies from leadership, management, systems and change theories to facilitate professional nursing practice.  Emphasis is placed on the professional nurse as a leader in the health care system.  The influence of organizational behavior, proactive political action, professional image and case management on nursing practice is examined.  For registered nurse students only.   This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategies from leadership, management, systems and change theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in the health care system

courseDescription: This capstone course is a practicum experience in which students apply theoretical, conceptual and psychomotor learning in a structured clinical environment under the supervision of a staff preceptor. The experience is designed to assist the student to facilitate the transition to the role of the baccalaureate generalist nurse.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of theoretical and conceptual nursing knowledge
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpersonal relations in a structured clinical environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration and application of learned concepts in practice situations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Facilitating transition to the role of a baccalaureate generalist nurse
Adapting to a structured clinical environment

courseDescription: This course focuses on professional nursing practice with families and communities as clients.  Emphasis is on community wellness, interaction with political influences and epidemiological principles.  For registered nurse students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with political influences on health care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with families and communities

courseDescription: The study of selected topics that may not be offered regularly.  Special topics will appear in the schedule of classes each semester.

This advanced placement credit is awarded to the registered nurse who has demonstrated knowledge of selected complex nursing concepts for the provision of nursing care to individuals and families experiencing health deviations. Awarded upon completion of 26 credits in the major.  For registered nurse students only.
Technical and Digital Skills: Provision of nursing care for health deviations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with individuals and families experiencing health deviations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and understanding of health deviations
Identification and application of appropriate nursing care
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization and execution of nursing care plans

courseDescription: This is an advanced placement course for registered nurse students. After verification of registered nurse licensure, the student will be awarded 33 experiential learning credits.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of medical digital tools and software

courseTitle: Principles of Practice: Contemporary Issues in Nursing Care of the Older Adult
courseDescription: This course focuses on the nursing needs of the well gerontological client. Emphasis is on the multi-complex needs of the older adult.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of multi-complex needs of older adults
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing personalized care plans for older adults

courseDescription: The study of selected topics that may  not be offered regularly.  Special topics will appear in the schedule of classes each semester.

This course provides for the award of credit for selected courses taken at Shenandoah University in fulfillment of Midwifery program requirements: NM 610, NM 620, NMLB 630, NM 640, NMLB 651, NM 652, and NM 660.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of midwifery procedures and techniques
Knowledge of prenatal, antenatal and postnatal care
Familiarity with medical tools and equipment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing emotional support and counseling to patients
Explaining complex medical terms in an understandable manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of patient's health condition
Identifying and managing complications during childbirth
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team of healthcare professionals
Adherence to healthcare laws and regulations

courseTitle: Shenandoah University Psychiatric Mental Health Courses
courseDescription: This course provides for the award of credit for selected courses taken at Shenandoah University in fulfillment of the Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner program requirements: NP 525,PMH 635, PMH 680,PMH 640, PMH 685, PMH 660, HP 576, PMH 695.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in psychiatric mental health nursing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of patient's mental health

courseTitle: Assessment and Evaluation in Nursing Education
courseDescription: This course concentrates on strategies to measure and improve nursing student performance in the classroom, as well as enhance course and program effectiveness.  Emphasis is on the selection of instruments, data collection methods and reporting procedures to guide assessment and evaluation processes that are appropriate for what is being examined.

courseTitle: Professional, Ethical and Legal Concepts of Nursing Education
courseDescription: This course is designed to prepare students for the role of educator in higher education environments. Emphasis is on the identification of functions, rights, and responsibilities of nursing faculty in relation to students, colleagues, administrators, the institution, community, and profession.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Maintaining professional relationships with students, colleagues, and administrators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of roles and responsibilities in nursing faculty
Understanding of nursing ethics and legalities

courseDescription: Thesis/research project completion.  Variable credit to be determined by research advisor. May be repeated as needed.
This course for the family nurse practitioner focuses upon primary health care problems in the pediatric population.  Emphasis is placed upon assessment and management of healthy and ill children.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of health care technology in pediatrics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Formulation of effective management plans for pediatric patients
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating with pediatric health care team
Organization of pediatric health care plans

courseDescription: This course will cover the use of data in health care as well as other informatics applications. Students will explore healthcare technology used to improve the delivery and evaluation of care.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading technology implementation in healthcare settings

courseDescription: This course focuses on the development of advanced nursing knowledge related to the utilization of evidence-based research for best practice. Emphasis is placed on the evaluation and application of research and evidence for use in advanced practice including models, concepts, and theories as a supporting framework for research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of nursing models, concepts, and theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of research and evidence
Application of research to solve nursing practice issues

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide the student involved in healthcare or healthcare supportive roles with knowledge and skills to become actively involved in the implementation and delivery of telehealth services.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data privacy and security in telehealth
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interdisciplinary collaboration in a digital environment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing technical issues in telehealth

courseDescription: This course focuses on the competitive design and utilization of organizational and human resources. Emphasis will be placed on the strategic process to ensure that resources are applied in ways to ensure high-quality care and excellent patient outcomes. The course will cover the business models for effective financial and personnel management of healthcare organizations. Analysis of the costs and quality of care will be performed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a healthcare setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Cost and quality of care analysis

courseTitle: Ethical Concepts of Advanced Practice Nursing
courseDescription: This course is designed to provide students with core ethical knowledge necessary to describe and analyze ethical concepts foundational to the advanced practice nursing role. Students will develop and evaluate strategies, including ethical decision making frameworks, to address ethical dilemmas inherent in patient care, health organizations and research.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of ethical decision making frameworks
Analysis of ethical concepts in nursing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing ethical dilemmas in patient care
Evaluating strategies to handle ethical issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of ethical concepts in healthcare
Dealing with ethical issues in health organizations

courseDescription: This practicum course emphasizes the advanced practice nurse's role in strategic planning and program development.  Students enrolled in this advanced practice course will participate in clinical practice experiences in a chosen focus area. This course is designed to provide students with experiences in applying the knowledge acquired in Strategic Leadership.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a clinical practice setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership within a clinical practice setting

courseTitle: Practicum Immersion for Novice Nurse Executives
courseDescription: This practicum course serves as a bridge between the roles of nurse administrators and nurse executives. Targeted practicum experiences will enable the nurse administrator to examine the role of the nurse executive related to implementation of change, meeting strategic initiatives, program evaluation, and outcome management in a chosen focus area. Application of futuristic and visionary theory to health care system trends is explored to provide optimal strategic positioning in the future healthcare market.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of change in healthcare settings
Outcome management in a chosen focus area
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with healthcare team for program evaluation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of strategic initiatives and programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic positioning in the healthcare market
Application of futuristic and visionary theory to healthcare systems

courseTitle: Family and Community Primary Care Assessment
courseDescription: This course provides students with the opportunity to develop advanced practice skills for assessing families and family members across the life span and throughout generations. This course will focus on theoretical, research and practice foundations used to develop strategies to maximize safe, comprehensive, and holistic care given by the advanced practice nurse.
Technical and Digital Skills: Advanced practice skills for family assessment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating with families across the lifespan
Collaborating with family members throughout generations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving problems related to family and community primary care

courseDescription: The enhancement of nursing education through an array of instructional delivery methods based on reports of best practices, research findings, instructional-related theories, and learning-related theories is examined. Emphasis is on identifying ways to blend traditional teaching strategies for classroom and clinical instruction with technology-based instruction utilizing a variety of resources and models.
Technical and Digital Skills: Blending traditional teaching strategies with technology-based instruction
Utilizing a variety of resources and models for instruction
Understanding research findings and instructional-related theories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting teaching strategies based on learner feedback
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of various teaching strategies
Identifying best practices in instructional delivery methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning of instructional delivery methods

courseDescription: This course explains the history of the specialty of geriatrics, the social impact, health maintenance goals and physical changes associated with aging. The role of interprofessional teams in meeting the needs of the aging population will be explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding physical changes associated with aging
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with the aging population
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and addressing the social impact of aging
Assessing the needs of the aging population
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating care for the aging population

courseDescription: This didactic course will introduce students to the process of history-taking and assessment of psychiatric mental health problems in the diagnosis of children through older adults and the process of using data from the patientâs history and assessment to formulate a differential diagnosis. Cultural, genetic, religious, behavioral, educational, physical, and laboratory data will be utilized in the formulation of differential diagnoses.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of cultural, genetic, religious, behavioral, educational, physical, and laboratory data for differential diagnosis

courseDescription: This course will examine the psychopharmacology of medications used to treat mental health disorders. It will also examine basic neurobiology and evaluate the intrinsic and extrinsic factors associated with the development of mental health disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to identify and understand different medications used to treat mental health disorders
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex pharmacological concepts
Articulating the roles of intrinsic and extrinsic factors in mental health disorders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of intrinsic and extrinsic factors associated with mental health disorders
Analytical understanding of the impact of medications on mental health disorders

courseTitle: Managing Psychiatric Disorders Across the Lifespan
courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity to gain knowledge of the management of mental health conditions across the lifespan, including child, adolescent, adult and older adult. Disparities across populations will be a component of the course. Culturally-centered, collaborative care will be emphasized in the preventive care and management of mental health disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in managing mental health conditions across the lifespan
Understanding of cultural disparities in mental health
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with different age groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and managing mental health disparities
Preventive care strategies for mental health disorders
Analyzing mental health conditions in different life stages
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing mental health care for different age groups
Guidance and leadership in preventive care

courseTitle: Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Practicum I
courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity for students to work in various psychiatric mental health environments focusing on a diverse population. The course will offer the opportunity to work with clinical mentors in their own communities. The time in these settings will allow students to begin their diagnosis and selection of appropriate treatment strategies, including medications and therapy, for individuals, families and groups with a wide variety of psychiatric mental health concerns.
Technical and Digital Skills: Diagnosis of psychiatric mental health concerns
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cultural competence in dealing with diverse populations
Ability to work effectively with individuals, families, and groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and evaluation of treatment effectiveness

courseTitle: Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Practicum II
courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity for students to build on previous clinical course work in various psychiatric mental health environments focusing on a diverse population. The time in these settings will allow students to enhance their diagnosis and selection of appropriate treatment strategies for individuals (child, adolescent, adult and older adult), families, and groups with a wide variety of psychiatric mental health concerns. This course requires 280 clinical hours.
Technical and Digital Skills: Diagnosis of psychiatric mental health concerns
Clinical practice in psychiatric mental health environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with individuals of diverse backgrounds
Interacting collaboratively with families and groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing a wide variety of psychiatric mental health concerns
Determining appropriate treatment strategies based on individual patient needs
Problem-solving in diverse psychiatric mental health environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading therapeutic sessions with individuals, families, and groups
Navigating various psychiatric mental health environments

courseTitle: Nursing Curricular Design and Program Evaluation
courseDescription: This course focuses on factors impacting the development of nursing curricula including theory, professional practice trends, education standards, accreditation guidelines and institutional policy/procedure. Components of curricula are evaluated, and strategies for program evaluation are explored.

This course develops the studentsâ ability to evaluate the maternal health record and assess and manage normal newborns. This is taken before the neonatal management courses and will provide a theoretical and practical knowledge for newborn assessment for the neonatal nurse practitioner to manage the health care needs of the normal newborn at the highest level of nursing practice.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with patients and their families

courseDescription: This internship course is designed to provide the student with experience facilitating classroom instruction in an entry level nursing program.
Technical and Digital Skills: Basic understanding of nursing program curriculum
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods based on student needs

courseTitle: Managing Psychiatric Disorders in Specific Populations: The Adult/Geriatric Patient
courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity to gain knowledge of the management of mental health conditions with the adult and geriatric patient populations. Disparities across the two populations will be a component of the course. Culturally centered, collaborative care will be emphasized in the preventive care and management of mental health disorders.Â  Appropriate care in a variety of treatment settings (inpatient, intensive outpatient, outpatient, forensic, long-term care) will be examined as well as legal ramifications for the PMHNP in treating this patient population.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of mental health conditions management
Understanding of adult and geriatric mental health disparities
Appropriate care delivery in various treatment settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative care for preventive and disorder management
Effective communication in inpatient, outpatient, intensive outpatient, forensic, long-term care settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and analysis of appropriate care in different treatment settings
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing preventive care and disorder management
Managing legal aspects in PMHNP treatment

courseTitle: Clinical Nurse Specialist I: Role Socialization
courseDescription: This course is designed to acquaint the student with the role of the Clinical Nurse Specialist in the practice environment.

This course provides an in-depth examination of human genetics, embryologic development and normal physiologic functioning of developing body systems. Mechanisms involved in cell division, gametogenesis, and inheritance patterns will be addressed. Basic genetics and epigenetics will be included. The structural and functional development of fetal systems, during critical periods, will be emphasized. Abnormalities and alterations in fetal development will be explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physiologic functioning of developing body systems
Understanding mechanisms involved in cell division
Knowledge on basic genetics and epigenetics
Understanding structural and functional development of fetal systems
Knowledge on abnormalities and alterations in fetal development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate complex genetic concepts
Explaining abnormalities and alterations in fetal development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of genetic and epigenetic data
Identification and interpretation of abnormalities in fetal development

courseTitle: Clinical Nurse Specialist II: Transition to Practice
courseDescription: This course provides the graduate student with knowledge necessary for developing Clinical Nurse Specialist practice and leadership skills.

courseTitle: Clinical Nurse Specialist Practicum II: Role Transition
courseDescription: This clinical course focuses on Clinical Nurse Specialist practice.  Concepts presented in the didactic component (NURSÂ 756) will be actualized in the clinical setting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing didactic concepts in a real-world setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of theoretical knowledge to practical situations

courseTitle: Clinical Nurse Specialist Practicum III: Role Synthesis
courseDescription: This capstone course focuses on synthesis and application of key concepts related to the Clinical Nurse Specialist practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of medical software and technology

courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity to practice clinical decision-making and primary care assessment skills within a primary care setting. Collaborative strategies will be emphasized in the position of health promotion/maintenance strategies and the management of common health problems.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a primary care setting

courseTitle: Advanced Family Nursing I: Management of Acute Illnesses
courseDescription: Focus is on acute health problems in the primary care setting, including assessment and management.  Inclusion of geriatric content relating to acute illnesses will be added.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Multidisciplinary coordination in a primary care setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of patient health status
Analytical skills for diagnosis and treatment selection
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a primary care setting
Organization of patient care under acute conditions

courseDescription: This course provides the nurse practitioner student the opportunity to work with students from other professions as they develop health promotion strategies that consider the expertise of each discipline. Students will incorporate technology in promoting health.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of technology in health promotion

courseDescription: The purpose of this clinical course is to prepare the family nurse practitioner student to deliver primary care services to families in which a patient has either acute, womenâs health or pediatric care disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Management of acute, womenâs health, and pediatric care disorders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Diagnosis of acute, womenâs health, and pediatric care disorders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management in a clinical setting

courseTitle: Advanced Family Nursing II: Management of Chronic Illnesses
courseDescription: The focus of this course is on the accurate diagnosis and management of chronic health problems within the primary care setting for the family nurse practitioner (FNP).
Technical and Digital Skills: Accurate diagnosis of chronic health problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing treatment plans for chronic illnesses

courseDescription: This course will explore current clinical concepts related to the care of healthy and pregnant women. Roles and responsibilities of the family nurse practitioner in these sub-specialties will also be discussed.

This clinical emphasizes integration of primary care skills and clinical course decision-making in populations with acute chronic, complex, pediatric or womenâs health disorders for family nurse practitioner students.
This course explains the pathophysiology of disease as a basis for advanced practice and assessment for prevention and management of health conditions.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Diagnosis of health conditions based on pathophysiology

courseTitle: Physical Assessment for Advanced Nursing Practice
courseDescription: Emphasis is on advanced history taking, physical assessment and interviewing skills for advanced practice nursing. Advanced practice students will participate in lab sessions with experiential activities allowing for the development of physical assessment skills across the lifespan.
Technical and Digital Skills: Interviewing techniques for advanced practice nursing

courseDescription: The foundations of advanced neonatal care course provides the theoretical and practical knowledge for the neonatal nurse practitioner or physician assistant to manage the health care needs of the neonate in the newborn nursery or level II neonatal intensive care unit.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of neonatal intensive care unit equipment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Diagnosis and treatment of neonatal conditions

courseDescription: The course offers scientific inquiry into the use of pharmacologic agents in the advanced nursing care of infants, including fetal, neonatal life, and early childhood. Pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, drug use in pregnancy and lactation, pharmacologic agents used in disease prevention and treatment, drug monitoring and drug safety in the home are explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with pharmacologic agents used in disease prevention and treatment
Comprehension of drug use in pregnancy and lactation
Adept in drug monitoring and drug safety in the home
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex pharmacological concepts to non-medical family members
Collaborative work with nursing and medical team
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret drug effects on infants
Critical evaluation of drug safety in different scenarios
Ability to adapt pharmacological treatments according to individual patient's needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and educating families for safe home drug administration

courseTitle: Advanced Neonatal Care: High Risk Management I
courseDescription: This course develops the students' ability to manage high-risk neonates. This is the second of three sequential management courses that provide the theoretical and practical knowledge for the neonatal nurse practitioner to manage the health care needs of the neonate at the highest level of nursing practice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Practical application of theoretical knowledge in neonatal care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a healthcare setting
Collaboration with healthcare team in managing neonatal care
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of neonate health status

courseTitle: Advanced Neonatal Care: High Risk Management II
courseDescription: An organ systems approach is used to explore the diagnosis and management of neonates requiring surgery and advanced technologies. Additional topics will include developmental follow-up of the medically fragile infant and withdrawal of life support in the NICU.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of advanced neonatal healthcare technologies
Understanding and application of organ systems approach
Proficiency in diagnosing neonatal health conditions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with parents and families during critical care situations
Conveying complex medical information to non-medical audience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment and management of high risk neonates
Analyzing developmental follow-up of the medically fragile infant
Decision making in withdrawal of life support scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating care for medically fragile infants
Leading critical care teams in the NICU

courseDescription: The development of foundational skills associated with the physical assessment and management of the neonate is the focus of this practicum experience.
The focus of this course is the accurate diagnosis and management of high risk neonatal clinical problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Accurate diagnosis of high risk neonatal clinical problems
Management of high risk neonatal clinical problems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and their families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of neonatal health conditions
Adapting treatment strategies based on individual patient needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Prioritizing patient care in high risk situations

courseTitle: Seminar in Pediatrics: Management of Chronic and Complex Neonatal Clinical Problems
courseDescription: This course utilizes a journal club approach and is designed to acquaint the advance practice neonatal nurse with issues associated with the management of chronic and complex clinical problems. Emphasis is on the identification of clinical conditions requiring timely referral for diagnosis and treatment. Topics will include, but are not limited to, genetics and congenital conditions, palliative/end-of-life care and complications of prematurity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in genetics and congenital conditions
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective referral for diagnosis and treatment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of chronic and complex neonatal clinical problems
Problem-solving in management of chronic neonatal conditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of chronic and complex clinical problems

courseTitle: Advanced Pediatric Nursing: Practicum I Primary Care
courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity to practice clinical decision-making and primary care assessment skills within a primary care setting. Collaborative strategies will be emphasized related to health promotion/maintenance and the management of common health problems for pediatric patients and their families.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with pediatric patients and their families
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing patient symptoms and health conditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordination and management of patient care
Leadership in a primary care setting

courseTitle: The Growth and Development of Children in the 21st Century
courseDescription: Physical, cognitive, psychosocial, psychosexual, and social-moral growth and development milestones from infancy through adolescence will be explored from a nursing perspective. Emphasis is on the assessment and management of the child within the context of environmental, cultural, and social factors affecting growth and development.
Technical and Digital Skills: Management of child within environmental, cultural, and social contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating with children from diverse backgrounds
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating child care in a nursing context

courseTitle: Management of Acute Pediatric Conditions I
courseDescription: An organ systems approach is used to explore the diagnosis and management of childhood disorders. The actions of the PNP and PEDS CNS and the needs of the child are considered across the continuum of care from urgent/primary care to acute care.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of organ systems in pediatrics
Knowledge of the care continuum from urgent/primary to acute care
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing the needs of the child patient
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of pediatric conditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and coordinating care for pediatric patients
Applying PNP and PEDS CNS actions in patient care

courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity to practice clinical decision-making and primary care assessment skills within a primary care setting. Collaborative strategies will be emphasized related to health promotion/maintenance and the management of common health problems for pediatric patients and their families.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with pediatric patients and their families
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading healthcare teams in a primary care setting

courseTitle: Seminar in Pediatrics: Management of Chronic and Complex Clinical Conditions
courseDescription: This course explores issues associated with the management of chronic and complex clinical conditions for children. Emphasis is on the identification of clinical conditions requiring timely referral for diagnosis and treatment.  Topics will include, but are not limited to genetics, palliative/end-of-life care, and psychiatric/mental issues.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of palliative and end-of-life care
Understanding of psychiatric and mental issues in children
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with patients and their families
Empathy and sensitivity in dealing with pediatric patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Timely referral for diagnosis and treatment
Critical assessment of complex clinical conditions
Problem-solving in complex and chronic pediatric conditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of chronic and complex clinical conditions

courseTitle: Management of Acute/Critical Pediatric Conditions II
courseDescription: An organ systems approach is used to explore the diagnosis and management of childhood disorders. The actions of the PNP and the needs of the child are considered across the continuum of care from urgent/primary care to acute /critical care.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Comprehension of child needs across care continuum
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solution providing for diverse childhood disorders
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of care from urgent/primary to acute/critical
Adapting to rapidly changing medical situations

courseDescription: This course provides the opportunity to practice clinical decision-making and primary care assessment skills within a primary care setting. Collaborative strategies will be emphasized related to health promotion/maintenance and the management of common health problems for pediatric patients and their families.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in a primary care setting

courseDescription: The focus of this course is on the accurate diagnosis and management of high risk neonatal clinical problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Accurate diagnosis of neonatal clinical problems
Management of high risk neonatal clinical problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of neonatal patient condition
Analytical skills for diagnosing complex neonatal issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in high-risk neonatal care settings

courseDescription: Designed to provide the advanced student with an opportunity to investigate specific topics of current interest in the health services.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing health service research projects

courseDescription: This course is for students completing an independent study or independent clinical hours.
This course focuses on clinical and/or research-related competencies of graduate nursing students. Students enroll on an as-needed basis as determined by the instructor or student.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clinical staff and patients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of nursing theories in practice
Identification and resolution of clinical problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Supervision and leadership in clinical settings

courseTitle: Integrative Concepts for Advanced Nursing Practice Roles
courseDescription: This course focuses on four integrative concepts including leadership, advocacy, practice, and translational research. Issues related to planning and providing care related to disparity and issues for vulnerable and underserved populations will be highlighted. The role of epidemiology will be explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Planning and providing care for disparity-related issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Advocacy for vulnerable and underserved populations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing care for vulnerable and underserved populations

courseTitle: Roles and Responsibilities for Transforming Practice
courseDescription: This course focuses on role expectations for advanced practice nurses; the intersection of models of leadership, advocacy, practice and translational research will be emphasized. Personal strategic planning of the students will be addressed as it applies to disparity issues and vulnerable and underserved populations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of disparity issues
Development and implementation of strategic plans

courseTitle: The Business of Advanced Nursing Practice
courseDescription: This course will explore the business dimensions of practice including legal, safety, quality and financial. The course will focus on SWOT analysis,developing business plans and community assessments.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of safety and quality standards
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in business planning and execution

courseTitle: Leadership and Interprofessional Practice in Healthcare
courseDescription: This is an interprofessional course that explores organizational and structural opportunities and barriers within healthcare organizations through interprofessional collaboration and teamwork. Ethical issues will be explored. The focus is on the role of the healthcare provider as a leader of their profession within healthcare and on healthcare teams. Emphasis is on meeting the needs of underserved populations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and overcoming barriers within healthcare organizations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and navigating healthcare organization structures

courseDescription: This course focuses on the research process used to conduct practice-based research.  It prepares advanced practice nurses to develop, implement, and evaluate programs that focus on improving healthcare outcomes.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a healthcare setting

courseDescription: This research course is designed to provide the Advanced Practice Nurse and Nurse Executive student with knowledge and skills regarding the design and methodology used to conduct a practice focused research study. Focus will be on human subjects protection, statistical analysis and database management.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ensuring compliance with human subjects protection practices

courseDescription: This course will cover the use of data in health care as well as other informatics applications.  Students will explore healthcare technology used to improve the delivery and evaluation of care.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of technology-driven care delivery improvements

courseTitle: Advocacy for Healthcare Public Policy for Advanced Practice
courseDescription: This course will prepare the DNP to assume a leadership role in developing, implementing, and advocating for health care policy that results in quality, accessible, comprehensive health care for vulnerable populations.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying healthcare needs of vulnerable populations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning for healthcare policy implementation

courseTitle: Leadership in Complex Systems and Organizations
courseDescription: This course will focus on the leadership that comprises two types:  informal and formal leadership.  Competencies will include communication, knowledge of health care environment, leadership, professionalism, and business skills.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional interaction in a healthcare environment

courseDescription: The focus of the course is on the development of systems  processes to ensure quality healthcare.  The evidence-based model will be applied to organizational systems.

This course focuses on the competitive design and utilization of organizational and human resources.  Emphasis wiil be placed on the strategic process to ensure that resources are applied in ways to ensure high-quality care and excellent patient outcomes.  The course will cover the business models for effective financial and personnel management of healthcare organizations.  Analysis of the costs of care and quality of care will be performed.
This practicum focuses on the application of nurse executive leadership skills in the practice environment. Focus will be on the role of the nurse executive and evidence-based research.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Role execution as a nurse executive

courseDescription: This experience focuses on the application of executive leadership skills in nursing. Focus will be on the role of the nurse executive and evidence-based research.

This practicum focuses on the application of executive leadership skills in the practice environment. Focus will be on the role of the nurse executive, evidence-based research and the use of healthcare technology.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a healthcare setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in a medical practice environment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Role fulfillment as a nurse executive

courseDescription: An examination of the application of executive leadership skills in the practice environment. Focus will be on the role of the nurse executive, evidence-based research, and practice dissemination.

This course is designed to provide the Advanced Practice Nurse with the knowledge and skills to practice at an advanced level in a practice-based setting. Focus will be on enhanced clinical skills and evidence-based research.

This course is designed to provide the Advanced Practice Nurse with the knowledge and skills to practice at an advanced level in a practice-based setting. Focus will be on evidence-based practice, teamwork, evidence-based research, and advanced clinical diagnostics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a practice-based setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing a health care team

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide the Advanced Practice Nurse with the knowledge and skills to practice as an expert clinician, a program evaluator, and a team leader within a practice-based setting focusing on evidence-based practice. Healthcare technology will be explored.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing team tasks within practice-based settings

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide the Advanced Practice Nurse with the knowledge and skills to practice as an expert clinician, a program evaluator, a team leader, and a change agent with emphasis on translational and evidence-based research.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a healthcare team

courseDescription: This capstone course is designed to facilitate the ability of the advanced practice nurse to synthesize, translate, and disseminate practice-focused research findings and apply them to practice settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of research findings to practice settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of research outcomes and applications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Translation of research findings into practice
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and applying research in practice settings

courseDescription: Designed to provide the advanced doctoral student with an opportunity to investigate specific topics of current interest in the health services.
This course focuses on research-related competencies of graduate nursing students. Students enroll on an as-needed basis as determined by the instructor.
This course focuses on clinical and/or research-related competencies of DNP graduate nursing students. Students enroll on an as-needed basis as determined by the instructor.

This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.

This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Maintaining active status in doctoral program
